test.name: SESSION-BASED TEST SETUP - DESKTOP (OR LAPTOP) : Set up this testing session and collect some information from the tester.

kw.name: Setup Session Based Test And Gather Information
Take Screenshot
kw.doc: Takes a screenshot in JPEG format and embeds it into the log file.

kw.name: Pause Execution
kw.doc: Pauses test execution until user clicks ``Ok`` button.

arguments.arg:
SESSION-BASED TEST SETUP - DESKTOP (OR LAPTOP) :



 This is session number ${SESSION_NUMBER}. ${TESTER_NAME}, please use this time to set up your Session-based Test for GitHub PR number ${PULL_REQUEST_NUMBER}, for Jira Task Number ${JIRA_TASK_NUMBER}. Also please be aware of any time restrictions for this session.



 For example, maybe you could git clone the repo of the system-under-test. 

 After cloning the repo, here are some interesting approaches that could possibly assist you... http://google-engtools.blogspot.com/2011/12/bug-prediction-at-google.html 

 There is also a machine learning bug prediction tool called gitrisky... https://github.com/hinnefe2/gitrisky

 ^ Bug hotspot detection and prediction are only suggestions, and you should not limit yourself. Read the following "A Context-Driven Approach to Automation in Testing" article for more information... http://www.satisfice.com/articles/cdt-automation.pdf 



 When you are ready to continue press OK. 

 There will be additional dialog boxes with required fields that will ask for more information.

kw.name: Get Value From User
kw.doc: Pauses test execution and asks user to input a value.

arguments.arg:
SESSION CHARTER - DESKTOP (OR LAPTOP) :



 Please provide a detailed but brief description of the mission statement for this test. 



 If you are not sure how to do this, specific information can be found here... http://www.satisfice.com/sbtm/
Please fill out this required field.

kw.msg: ${SESSION_CHARTER} = This test will cover the data processors that collect data from the enterprise service bus, and sends it to the normalizers and event store.

kw.name: Get Value From User
kw.doc: Pauses test execution and asks user to input a value.

arguments.arg:
FUNCTIONAL AREAS COVERED - DESKTOP (OR LAPTOP) :



 Please provide a specific list of the areas that will be covered in this testing session.



 If you are not sure how to do this, specific information can be found here... http://www.satisfice.com/sbtm/
Please fill out this required field.

kw.name: Get Value From User
kw.doc: Pauses test execution and asks user to input a value.

 Please follow the given example to provide metrics and information about...

 DURATION

 DATA FILES



 If you are not sure how to do this, specific information can be found here... http://www.satisfice.com/sbtm/

Please fill out this required field, using the following example... DURATION -> short, TEST DESIGN AND EXECUTION -> 100, BUG INVESTIGATION AND REPORTING -> 0, SESSION SETUP -> 0, CHARTER VS. OPPORTUNITY -> 100/0, DATA FILES -> staging-user-profiles.csv

TEST RESULT FOR GITHUB PR NUMBER ${PULL_REQUEST_NUMBER} - JIRA TASK NUMBER ${JIRA_TASK_NUMBER} - DESKTOP (OR LAPTOP) :



 Please make sure you read and understand all of the information in the GitHub PR and the Jira Task before continuing. If needed, pair with the developer who worked on it to make sure you understand what was done. 



 When you are ready to move on, please press PASS or FAIL and be prepared to enter notes into the Robot Framework Dialog Box.
Please provide precise details about all of the issues you found. If necessary, you should take additional screenshots and upload them somewhere accessible (S3, Google Drive, etc.)...

suite.doc: In a hypothetical scenario, where you are split between 3 or more frequently changing projects. Several of them are maybe, days, weeks or months past their delivery date. You are brought in to quickly learn everything about the project and set up basic regression tests touching all of the high risk areas, running in the CI pipeline in less than 10 working days (ideally they want it in probably 5 days or less). This might be a situation where people are relying on various types of tools to test things out and quickly explore system behavior, maybe there are dozens of cURL one-liners being shared by the developers...

suite.doc: In a hypothetical scenario, where you are split between 3 or more frequently changing projects. Several of them are maybe, days, weeks or months past their delivery date. You are brought in to quickly learn everything about the project and set up basic regression tests touching all of the high risk areas, running in the CI pipeline in less than 10 working days (ideally they want it in probably 5 days or less). This might be a situation where people are relying on various types of tools to test things out and quickly explore system behavior, maybe there are dozens of cURL one-liners being shared by the developers...

This keyword turns the cURL examples into an API fuzz testing tool that can run in serial or in parallel.

suite.doc: In a hypothetical scenario, where you are split between 3 or more frequently changing projects. Several of them are maybe, days, weeks or months past their delivery date. You are brought in to quickly learn everything about the project and set up basic regression tests touching all of the high risk areas, running in the CI pipeline in less than 10 working days (ideally they want it in probably 5 days or less). This might be a situation where people are relying on various types of tools to test things out and quickly explore system behavior, maybe all of the developers like using Postman (with Newman) and are sharing a single Postman Collection that keeps growing bigger every day. This example is enhanced in Part Two...

suite.name: Robot Framework test run with a Postman Newman Collection running one Postman Folder at a time in serial random order

suite.doc: Part Two of the Postman Newman example has been enhanced by using the SharedKeywordsAndListeners.robot resource file to add 2 types of Robot Framework listeners and a team notification keyword. Also added the "--randomize tests" option in the commands-running-inside-a-docker-container.sh script, and will demonstrate the use of the "--rerunfailedsuites".

suite.doc: In a hypothetical scenario, where you are split between 3 or more frequently changing projects. Maybe you were able to convince your team leaders and developers to provide you with some help building out the Robot Framework regression tests. The following assumes that the team member helping you is most likely a developer. The developer helping you is comfortable with contributing to a test that uses a few keywords from the standard Robot Framework BuiltIn Library, and the rest is handled by a user-created library. In this case the library is written in Python...
